text: Armindo Silva opens the conference and outlines a new report that will be presented today on occupational diseases.
"Together for disease-free workers" is the theme of the conference.  @Social_Europe
Good morning. EU-OSHA is attending the big European Commission conference in Brussels today on occupational disease. @Social_Europe
@nlyozz thank you! See you soon, Brenda Chief Tweeter.
@JamesLascelle thanks For your question.  If you are interested in more info on the Austrian experience email me obrien@osha.europa.eu
@nlyozz thank you, Jos. Glad you liked the tweets. Brenda
And thank you for following @EU_OSHA
Finally, just another reminder.  We will put all of the presentations on our website in the next days.
Ms Bauer thanked all the contributors and said that the European Parliament was very interested in this topic and would continue to be so.
Recently, EU-OSHA published its OSH research priorities report.  It is very important for us.  Ageing is crucial for our future work.
Demographic change allows us once again to stress the importance of OSH, says Dr Sedlatschek. Workers, companies and economies are concerned
The Director, Christa Sedlatschek, said that she heard a lot of very good ideas during the conference.
Ms Moitinho said that we all need to feel well in our work.  She thanked the organizers.
Ms Moitinho said the conference will be timely and will coincide with the ex post evaluation of the OSH directives.  #atanyage
Ms Moitinho said that it was clear that the approach should be holistic involving research, education and the current economic context.
Ms Moitinho said that educating the young in schools on workplace risks will work.  She is convinced of its value.
Ms Moitinho of the European Commission said that we should start this preventive culture in school.
Ms Moitinho said that the afternoon was very interesting.  She reiterated the general principles of prevention.These should guide our work.
Ms Bauer said that we need a lot of research in this field as the reality is so complex.
Ms Bauer says that the issue is hidden and that is why the EP asked the Commission to come up with a strategy in the area of older workers.
Ms Bauer MEP from Slovakia says there are plenty of challenges here, given the rapid social and technological changes in our societies.
Ms Copsey wants to get a lot of intermediaries involved in the workshops.  And yes, we will have to prioritize.  That is clear.
We choose the smaller group by targeting those countries where we knew some things were happening and share information.
How did we choose the Member States? We are covering all of them in our inventory and then in-depth analysis of a smaller group.
Ms Copsey says the project aims to see what is going on in practice and compare it with policy objectives.  Is implementation measuring up?
Prof Ilmarinen says the great challenge is to prioritize the actions.  What are the most acute actions needed?  Prioritize! #atanyage
In Austria, there is a focus on the ageing workforce in the labour inspection.  It is a very practical approach. I hope we can learn more!
Gertrud Breindl from the Austrian Ministry of Labour asked about the 8 Member States and Austria's participation. How deep will research go?
Professor Ilmarinen says that the role of technology is polarizing our working life.  Older workers must use the technology more.
@AragonValley You are very welcome!  Greetings from chilly Brussels.
Ms Bauer said that the EMPL Committee is very happy to have two such competent agencies as Eurofound and EU-OSHA.
Jean Michel Miller from Eurofound said that they were running projects on sustainable work.
Rolf Gehring emphasizes the importance of design in the world of safety.
Teresa Moitinho from the European Commission rejoins the podium to take part in the discussion with participants. http://t.co/MkygCYrvRa
Health inequalities in the UK is a big issue, says a participant from the UK.These should be improved for everyone, not just for older ones!
There is more information available on physical illnesses but very little around the issue of mental health, says Ms Dupont. #atanyage
Conference in the European Parliament on Safer and Healthier Work at Any Age. http://t.co/MVEQWwbbEO
In Member States, retirement ages are rising.  There is a lack of policies targeting older workers. #atanyage
We don't have enough information about older workers and exposure to chemicals, says Ms Dupont. #atanyage
Physiological and psychological changes impact older workers and there is a distinct gender issue, says Clare Dupont.
Prevention is really essential, says Ms Dupont.  #atanyage
Ms Claire Dupont presents some preliminary results as the project is still in the early phase. #atanyage
we need integrated policies and joined-up strategies, says Sarah Copsey.  This will require different ways of working.
Increasing sedentary work, says Sarah Copsey, is a major contributor to health or ill health.  Studies show schoolkids already have problems
Sarah takes the example of a French printing company which had a poor record.  With some help, they identified age and gender issues.
Sarah Copsey emphasizes how risk assessment can include the issue of ageing.  It's simple and effective. #atanyage
Sarah Copsey emphasizes the life-cycle approach to ageing workers.  OSH policies and strategies need to be sensitive to age.  How?
The project will look at what is going on, what works and what needs to change?  What is appropriate?
And it's not good enough to dump all the heavy work on the young.  That is not the answer, says Sarah Copsey. #atanyage
It's not just about older workers but what occupational health system do we need for ALL workers, knowing what we do about ageing?
Final report will be discussed at a conference in June 2015.
Sarah Copsey now gives an overview of the big EU-OSHA project on Safer and Healthier Work at any Age.  #atanyage
@UNISON_HS Thank you, Unison.
Ms De Broeck says that age is not the most influential issue when looking at work ability. #atanyage
Dr Ball says that there are clearly big and inescapable challenges that require engagement of employers. It is an opportunity for all.
Prof Ilmarinen says that younger and older workers are the most vulnerable. They require different management approaches.
Mr Kempa says fitness cannot solve the problems in the workplace.  Many occupational diseases come from exposure to chemicals, for example.
Viktor Kempa from ETUI thinks that the situation is getting worse because of attacks on occupational health services. #atanyage
The EU needs to look at its own policies and at pension policies too.
Rolf Gehring from the construction trade unions comments that the precarious nature of employment is crucial and exposure to new hazards.
Shortly we will present the first preliminary results of the EU-OSHA project on Safer and Healthier Work at Any Age.  Can't wait.
Dr Aust emphasizes the importance of management support.  #atanyage
Programmes are demanding and implementation must be done properly, otherwise results will be poor, says Dr Aust. #atanyage
By the way, in the next days all of today's presentations will be posted on our website https://t.co/mqeLVyqQ4G
Dr Aust describes the Danish programme dedicated to reintegration.  #atanyage
@SharkeyMarg keep the faith.  we all have our bad days...
Dr Aust shifts the focus to disability and reintegration into the working environment.  #atanyage
The next speaker is Dr Birgit Aust from the National Research Centre for the Working Environment in Denmark.
Employers that have good OSH policies often encourage healthy activities too.  They are important. @TAEN_Uk
Dr Ball says that we are all living longer but not all of us are living healthily. #atanyage
Dr Ball reminds us that age discrimination is unlawful, but it is widespread. #atanyage
TAEN not TAME as previously posted erroneously.  @TAEN_Uk
When we see good practice we should give credit, says Dr Ball.  @Social_Europe @TAEN_Uk @FIOH
TAME works with employers and trade unions in the UK, to ensure that the process of social dialogue takes into account ageing and work.
Next to speak here in the European Parliament is Dr Chris Ball of The Age and Employment Network in the UK.  'Im nearly 70!' he says.
Young workers are at their best on Fridays, ready for the weekend.  Older workers are at their best on Mondays!
We need better health services.  Every country needs a national programme taking these issues into consideration.  #atanyage
We need age friendly and age adjusted workplaces, says Prof Ilmarinen.
We need to create positive attitudes to ageing, says the Finnish professor.  Managers need to learn this.
What have we learned from national programmes?  We have to increase the awareness level about ageing.
We need a new paradigm for good work.  This paradigm is workplace wellbeing. People should love what they are doing, says Prof Ilmarinen.
But in order to work longer, we need jobs and lay-offs often start with the older workers.
We need to understand that we all CAN work longer, says Professor Ilmarinen.  #atanyage
https://t.co/mqeLVyqQ4G
Regrettably older people show lower work ability indices because the workplaces are not changing as we grow older.
The work ability index allows us to measure the concept and is used in 28 countries across the world.
Prof Ilmarinen introduces the notion of work ability in the context of an ageing workforce.
Next up is Professor Juhani Ilmarinen from Finland, renowned world expert on the ageing workforce. #atanyage
Good practice examples exist and legislation and national programmes can be very supportive and extremely important for older workers.
There is a misquided belief that we all want to retire earlier.  Studies show the opposite.  Many of us want to work for as long as possible
There is a clear business case for employing older workers, says Ms De Broeck.  #atanyage @enwhp
We just need a clearer understanding of how ageing affects workers and workplaces.  We need to debunk the myths about older workers.
There is a great need for changes in company policies.  There is widespread discrimination, says Ms De Broeck.
Ms De Broeck introduces the network and the work they are doing on extending working lives.
Next up is Veronique De Broeck from the European Network Workplace Health Promotion @enwhp@Social_Europe #atanyage
Christa Sedlatschek introduces the current research project, with its ambitious targets and objectives.  #atanyage
Agency Director says that we have to meet the demographic challenge if we are going to achieve Europe2020 goals. #atanyage
#atanyage Agency Director, Christa Sedlatschek, presents the demographic trends and stresses the impact on society.
The recent consultation on a new OSH strategy has been very positive, with a majority believing that EU has a role in fostering our health.
There is a great need to integrate occupational safety and health into the broader health picture, says the European Commission.
Many factors can help ageing people to fully participate in the workplace.
Ms Moitinho says a lot of myths abound about older workers.  They do not take more sick leave or have higher absenteeism rates.#atanyage
Older workers represent a greater proportion of the workforce and many cannot reach their retirement ages due to poor working conditions.
Maria-Teresa Moitinho from the European Commission says that there is a major interested now in sustainable working lives. #atanyage
#olderworkers #EUParliament #atanyage.  Edit Bauer says that this issue is a burning one and the conference is timely.
#atanyage our conference on Safer and Healthier Work at any Age will kick off shortly.  It is chaired by Edit Bauer, MEP, from Slovakia.
#atanyage check out our event this afternoon in the #EUParliament.  Safe and healthy work at any age.  Will be tweeting from 15,30 cet.

Participation of everyone in health and safety is essential for success, Professor Trimpop #EU_OSHA_Summit
Occupational stress is related to 40% of lost working time in Germany - Professor Trimpop #EU_OSHA_Summit
Professor Trimpop, University of Jena talks about importance of worker participation at healthy workplaces summit #EU_OSHA_Summit
Day two of the Healthy Workplaces Summit on Working Together for Risk Prevention about to start! Follow us here #EU_OSHA_Summit
Dietmar Elsler discusses the great contribution of official campaign partners to the campaign and benchmarking initiative #EU_OSHA_Summit
Tom Schalenbourg Sustainable Development Director, Toyota Manual Handling presents on reporting standards in OSH #EU_OSHA_Summit
Workshop on benchmarking in OSH. #EU_OSHA_Summit
Francesca Grosso, INAIL presents the Dissemination of prevention culture to a wide audience through OSH campaign in Italy. #EU_OSHA_Summit
Workshop on successful networking and campaigning in OSH. Successful campaigns need partnerships - working together #EU_OSHA_Summit
Online risk assessments help to focus on health and safety issues. Brendan McGarry of West Offaly Dairy Discussion Group #EU_OSHA_Summit
RT @PPEorg: Behind each accident are people and families - Juan Maria Aburto, Basque Govt. @EU_OSHA #EU_OSHA_Summit #EU_OSHA

Here is the report again and check out our website for more info.  Bye for now. https://t.co/bd75x2gQg5
Dr Sedlatschek thanked the Belgian Ministry for the facilities.  She was very grateful for their assistance.  Also, thanks to Commission.
The agency will publish all of these publications shortly.  If you need one urgently, let us know.
Dr Sedlatschek focused on quality of work.  We don't always have to focus on growth, rather on social stability.
In EU-OSHA we will try to support national efforts and keep OSH on the political agenda.  The climate is very difficult.
Dr Sedlatschek said that we are a European network agency and we are worried by the lack of an EU OSH Strategy and cuts at national level.
Dr Sedlatschek will examine more closely the Commission inter-service  consultation on Horizon 2020.
The Director of EU-OSHA summarizes.  First, a thank you to all participants.  A smaller expert group will be formed.
If you want more info on EUWIN, don't forget we will post all conference presentations on our website very soon.
Prof Pot says that the programme supports EU2020 and the subsidies are eligible for block exemptions.  EUWIN is run by DG Enterprise.
Professor Pot presents EUWIN "European Workplace Innovation Network"
Final speaker today, Frank Pot, Emeritus Professor of Social Innovation of Work and Employment, Nijmegen School of Management, Radbout Uni.
14 countries are involved in this FPI with three further observers.  Mr Harma encourages others to get involved and avoid data gaps.
By the way, Ms Albin said earlier that OSH was in a tight spot in Sweden (cuts).  Not a right spot.  That was a typing error. Sorry.
Research for demographic change requires an interdisciplinary and holistic approach across different domains, says Mr Harma.
http://t.co/om7InWWmLX is useful website for JPI information.
The aim of this JPI is to elaborate a strategic research agenda with coordination and implementation components at EU and national level.
Next up is Mikko Harma from FIOH presenting the Joint Programming Initiative (JPI): More years, better lives.
Sweden is anxious to develop an advocacy strategy, both national and European, says Ms Albin.  Working together is the key.
In Sweden, Ms Albin says labour market is polarized, highly gendered labour market.
In Sweden, researchers working together with lots of support from social partners but OSH is in a right spot. Funding cuts.
Maria Albin, Lund University, Sweden presents "The Sustainable Workplace in Horizon 2020: A Swedish Platform."
Dr Sedlatschek, EU-OSHA, Director and meeting chair, said that it was very clear that more collaboration was needed in these austere times.
Occupational diseases are common; common diseases are occupational.  The evidence is there, says Dr Takala.
Dr Takala examined competitiveness and workplace safety and health. A clear correlation between good working conditions and competitiveness.
The ILO reckons the cost of injury and illness is 4 per cent of global GDP, says Dr Takala.  And the biggest burden is for the workers.
Economic cost of injury and illness: 3.2 per cent of GDP in Singapore in 2011, says Jukka Takala.
MSDs and depression still the largest non-fatal work-related illnesses.Work life expectancy and employment expectancy could be much better.
Dr Takala looks at work related illnesses by age and by gender.  Just a reminder - we will publish the presentations on our website shortly.
Lung cancer figure are hugely unreliable because the work-related component is vastly under reported, says Jukka Takala.
Cancer is still the main killer, says Jukka Takala, both in Europe and in Singapore.  Figures are still under-estimated, in his view.
Dr Takala advises the audience to be careful with comparing figures.
Singapore and Finland working together on producing figures for workplace fatalities which will be published next year.
Dr Takala says we should have more transfer studies on European and global levels and emphasizes international collaboration.
More research projects in Singapore include business case studies, risks and solutions.  They hire experts on topics such as nano exposure.
Some research priorities in Singapore: enhancing OSH leadership/culture, linking to productivity, imminent concerns, designing for health...
Dr TAKALA proposed the setting up of a Risk Observatory in Singapore, similar to the EU-OSHA experience.  It is now established.
Dr Takala provides an overview of the Singaporean context.  They have a national research agenda which runs to 2016.
Now we have the international perspective on research priorities, presented by Dr Jukka Takala from Singapore.
The European Commission representatives were from Research, Enterprise and Health areas.  We will post presentations later.
Three speakers from the European Commission kicked off the second morning of our OSH priorities conference in Brussels.
@LusisRenars thank you!
@AragonValley well thank you!
How about an accounting exercise of non-action in OSH, asks Erika Mezger, Eurofound.
RT @INRSfrance: Role of OSH research and its links to the EU strategy #movingtowards2020 with @EU_OSHA http://t.co/hEDyDSZHfK
Ms Graf from Switzerland says that intervention research is very unfashionable.  It's difficult to get it published.
Mr Kahr wonders what are success factors?  Probably, the ability to work together.  We should open up our research to this.
Mr Kahr from the Danish trade unions says the emphasis in report is on growth.  But public sector has different drivers for change.
It is a failure that EU2020 does not specifically refer to OSH.  National funding is being squeezed everywhere. We need this report!
Professor Vainio says that "improvement research" is key, looking at practical examples.We have a scientific pathway and a practical pathway
Teresa Moitinho says that only proper research can convince.
Teresa Moitinho says that more than ever we need research and we show benefits of investment in OSH.  We can show that OSH is essential.
Dr Sedlatschek said that there is a real fear out there without a proper EU OSH strategy.  We must support our SMEs and micro enterprises.
Dr Sedlatschek says that we should avoid creating two classes of workers, those in micro enterprises and the rest.
Mr TAKALA adds that we have been unable to globalize OSH research. This is another failure.  Too many occupational cancer deaths.  Aim high.
Dr TAKALA concludes that we must be more concrete and practical in our research findings.  Design for safety and design for health!
Another failure is that despite our excellent evidence, we no longer have an EU strategy.  We have failed to communicate its importance.
But, Mr Takala, reminds us that there are areas where we have failed.  We need research that shows evidence of impact.
Jukka Takala, Executive Director, Workplace Safety and Health Institute, Singapore, notes that fatal accidents are falling.
OSH research can inform policy action, says Ms Smith.  We should avoid research for research' sake.
Business Europe believes in the business case and prevention is key, says Rebekah Smith, Senior Adviser.
Ms Smith says that restructuring is a fact of life for companies.  We should facilitate it and not block it.  Social dialogue crucial.
Employers have a role to play, of course, says Ms Smith.  We should look at lifestyles too, both inside and outside of work.
Ms Smith says it's important to link OSH research priorities to EU2020.
Rebekah Smith, Business Europe, agrees on smart, sustainable and inclusive world of work, as outlined in EU2020.
EU-OSHA has a major role to play, according to Mr Kempa.
Mr Kempa has four OSH research priorities: chemical hazards; MSDs and other traditional diseases; new and emerging risks; socio-economic.
Mr Kempa says that workers should be involved in data-gathering.  Research should be participative.  Mainstream OSH research resources.
Mr Kempa says that EU legislation is under attack.  Very worrying.
Viktor Kempa says that EU2020 didn't even mention OSH specifically.  Now, OSH under renewed attack from the so-called REFIT.
Mr KEMPA says that things are so bad that OSH is reactive and national because of the lack of a strategy at EU level.
Viktor Kempa, from the European Trade Union Institute, says OSH is in trouble because at EU level there is no longer a strategy.
OSH research should be smart, inclusive and sustainable, says Mr Reinert.
Dietmar Reinert says that OSH research should be proactive, international and intervention-oriented.
Ms Mezger says that social partners are essential in the OSH debate.  Collective agreements are under threat, for example, in Portugal.
Ms Mezger emphasizes the good collaboration between EU-OSHA and EUROFOUND.
The Deputy Director of Eurofound, Erika Metzger, opens the panel discussion on the role of OSH research and its links to EU2020.
Dr Sedlatschek comments on the richness of the debate.  Expert input is so valuable, enabling us to refine the priority areas.
Risk communication is all about strategic leadership and must be performed more regularly.  Must add surveillance and social media, says Bye
We need more research into strategic communication on risk, according to our Norwegian guest, Dr Bye.
Risk communication is most functional when systematically performed, according to Dr Bye from Norway.
Dr Bye from Norway is an expert on risk communication.  It most often occurs when there is an actual crisis. A strong link here to research.
Here is the workplace health and safety research priorities report again. Check it out. https://t.co/bd75x2gQg5
Our Chair, Maria-Teresa Moitinho of the European Commission, is doing a great job keeping so many speakers in line and on time...
Dr Sture Bye from Norway takes to the podium.  The pace is fast in our OSH research priorities seminar.
Diesel engine exhaust.  Research is ongoing, says Dr Trainor from the UK.
Closely working with the Olympics before and during London 2012 has left a valuable learning legacy in the UK, says Dr Trainor.
Work-related accidents are dropping but have plateaued in the UK.  Biggest problem still in construction.
40 per cent of sick days in the UK due to work-related stress, says Dr Trainor.
Dr Mary Trainor, Head of Science, HSL UK, looks at translational research, & importance of science in goal-setting regulatory regime.
Finland is a greying country.  Presenteeism is a growing problem.  Need to look at SMEs and exposures, explained Professor Vainio.
Hypersensitivity syndromes such as multiple chemical sensitivity is a growing concern, according to Prof Vainio.
Insufficient data on exposure is the Achilles' heel in risk assessment and management, says Prof Vainio.
Chronic disease prevention is clearly a good investment.  Return to work programmes can have very beneficial economic impacts.
Mr Vainio presents new figures on the overall burden of disease in Western Europe. Cancer is still the major killer. MSDs and stress are up.
But, Prof Vainio cautions, have we too many priorities?  How can we get them into Horizon 2020?  This is a main issue for this conference!
Professor Harris Vainio, Director General of the Finnish Institute of Occupational Health, says the report is a major step in world of OSH.
OSH research should include more about health promotion at work, says Dr Lasfargues.
Dr Lasfargues emphasizes the precautionary principle and the proportionality approach.
RT @svaxelaire: #osh The former and the current @EU_OSHA Director attending #Movingtowards2020 meeting http://t.co/FmPQkYyKNh
Dr Lasfargues of the ANSES, France, looks at OSH research for safe new technologies.
Mr Iavicoli looks at ageing, fragmentation, externalization and migration as well as changes in governance.
Sergio Iavicoli, OSH Director, INAIL, compares our current experiences with the Industrial Revolution...
Dancing instead of boxing.  Innovation and productivity should dance together, not box, says Professor Bongers.
Good working conditions are a true asset, says Professor Bongers.  OSH must be integrated into workplaces using all the new technologies.
Prof Paulien Bongers of TNO in the Netherlands looks at globalization and the changing world of work.
In Germany, ministries are working together on the demographic issue.  Cross-departmental and inter-disciplinary research ongoing.
Mr Richter says that work can either accelerate or delay the process of ageing.
Also looking at the demographic challenges is Götz Richter from Germany's BAuA.  How can baby boomers continue?
In Denmark, there is a clear necessity to extend the span of working life participation.  Need to hold on to the older workers.
Nils Fallentin from Denmark addresses the demographic challenges ahead.

@rickytrips @EU_OSHA @EBC_SMEs @UEAPME 
Agreed!
Didier Baptiste, Scientific Director of INRS, takes to the stage.
And how can we ensure full synergy with the aims and objectives of Horizon 2020?  Such questions will be addressed during this conference.
How can we foster OSH research coordination and funding in the future, asks Director Sedlatschek.
Everyone's suffering budget cuts, so now more than ever we need to address the transfer of research results to Europe's workplaces.
The Agency will pursue a major project on micro enterprises over the next couple of years, says Director Christa Sedlatschek.
Here's the new report on future OSH research priorities https://t.co/bd75x2gQg5
The director introduces the Agency's new report on research priorities.  Check it out on our website.
Kicking off our seminar on future OSH research priorities in Brussels.  Lots of interest. #OSH
